name: Mirtazapine (Remeron)
summary: A noradrenergic and specific serotonergic antidepressant (NaSSA) used for major depressive disorder, often beneficial for patients with insomnia or poor appetite.
description: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant that works by antagonizing central presynaptic α2-adrenergic receptors, increasing norepinephrine and serotonin release, and blocking certain serotonin receptors (5-HT2, 5-HT3) while strongly antagonizing histamine H1 receptors. This combination can improve mood and anxiety while promoting sleep and increasing appetite. It is particularly useful in patients with depression accompanied by insomnia, weight loss, or poor appetite.

contraindications: Concurrent or recent (within 14 days) MAOI use

sections.text: Blocks presynaptic α2-adrenergic autoreceptors and heteroreceptors, enhancing norepinephrine and serotonin release; antagonizes 5-HT2 and 5-HT3 receptors, enhancing 5-HT1A–mediated neurotransmission; strong H1 receptor blockade leads to sedative effects.

adult.titrate: Increase by 15 mg every 1–2 weeks as needed

sections.geriatric: Start at 7.5–15 mg nightly, titrate slowly
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use lower initial doses; monitor closely
sections.renal_impairment: Mild to moderate: no adjustment; severe: use caution

items: Orally disintegrating tablets (ODT): 15 mg, 30 mg, 45 mg

sections.text: Sedative effects may occur within days; antidepressant effects typically appear within 1–2 weeks, with full benefit by 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Antidepressants increase the risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults.
other: May cause significant weight gain and sedation
Risk of agranulocytosis—monitor if signs of infection appear

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: More sensitive to sedative and weight gain effects

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over 1–2 weeks to minimize withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, irritability, and insomnia.

items: Lower doses (15 mg) tend to be more sedating than higher doses due to histamine blockade predominance
Often chosen for depressed patients with significant insomnia or weight loss
Less likely to cause sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs and SNRIs

seo.title: Mirtazapine (Remeron): Sedating Antidepressant for Depression & Insomnia
seo.description: Mirtazapine (Remeron) is an atypical antidepressant useful for depression, insomnia, and appetite stimulation. Learn about dosing, side effects, and precautions.
